Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think that --without-npm would not work for packages that rely on nodejs modules.

Patch Set 1:

I believe from the discussion in this review that there is a conceptual error about what npm is and what it does

I believe npm is basically the equivalent of cpan.  That is to say that just like with cpan for perl, you use npm to down load modules to your system from a huge database of modules on an internet server.

A distribution typically doesn't have a package just call into cpan, but instead actually grabs the source at packaging time and makes a proper package out of it like we do in tizen with tizen rpm's for various perl modules.  Not having cpan does not mean you can not use a perl module, it just means you can drop into the cpan terminal and search for and install from the remote server.

The demo mentioned before had an "install" which would call npm to download a bunch of modules off the remote server.  If that code wanted to be packaged on Tizen then somebody would need to download all those same files ahead of time and put that in the actual demo source.

ok... with all that said, yes, it would be a cool thing for developers to be able to experiment with nodejs and use npm to download arbitrary modules (and there are a ton of them).  The only reason i didn't enabled this by default is because nodejs does some very evil things in install of the npm source requiring some trickery in the spec file.  If figured out this trickery so will go ahead and submit a second patchset
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2:

The tag submit/tizen_ivi_genivi/20140225.213143 was pushed, but it was not completed because of the following reason(s):

- The tag means you want to submit commit ae108fbf071489b3635f7c9e612bfc2577051576 in tizen_ivi_genivi branch to OBS, but this commit does NOT exist in tizen_ivi_genivi branch. Please use correct branch name as version in tag name submit/{version}/{date.time}.

Suggest to use "gbs submit" to trigger submission, or use following command to create tag "git tag submit/${version}/$(date --utc +%%Y%%m%%d.%%H%%M%%S) -m "****" ".
